Award.AwardTitle: Engineering a Competitive Advantage using Synthetic Biology and Microfluidic Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project combines synthetic biology, microfluidic technology, and computational modeling to probe metabolic networks in three model organisms in dynamic environments and to study the evolutionary process of developing a competitive growth advantage. A synthetic genetic oscillator will control expression of essential metabolic enzymes in E. coli and Synechocystis (a cyanobacterium), and the growth characteristics of these engineered organisms in a periodically changing environment will be compared to wildtype, non-modified organisms. In yeast, synthetic biology and microfluidic technology will be used to "evolve" a well-characterized metabolic network and microscopy will be used to identify changes that confer a growth advantage in a dynamic environment. The combination of modeling and experimental approaches will provide insight into how organisms can be modified, either through engineered or natural evolutionary processes, to give them a growth advantage in fluctuating environments.

Broader Impacts: A quantitative understanding of microbial evolution will contribute to the development of new strategies to control microbial infections. An elementary school science program will be developed in partnership with the San Diego Unified and North County school districts. Project personnel and graduate students will work with elementary school teachers to prepare the graduate students to teach hands-on experimental science lessons that are integrated with the classroom curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By combining microfluidic technology and synthetic biology with quantitative modeling we explored various aspects of interaction of genetic circuits with fluctuating environments on population dynamics and evolutionary time scales.   Specifically, the followng key results were obtained with the support of this NSF grant.

- By combining existing, robust synthetic gene circuits constructed and characterized in our lab with each other and other components we demonstrated the important role of enzymatic coupling in synchronization of various cellular processes and and their adaptation to the dynamic environmental factors. Our results established a general framework for the rapid and tunable coupling of genetic circuits through the use of native "queueing" processes such as competitive protein degradation.

- We developed a novel conceptual approach to solving clomplex classification problems using diverse cellular populations that are shaped by specifically constructed  competitive advantage criteria during training. Our study opened an intriguing possibility to engineer genetically diversified microbial populations to solve classification tasks which are difficult or impossible to solve within a single microbial cell, which has important applications in the design of biological sensors.

- Our project led to the development of a novel efficient algrithm for simulating long-term evolutionary processes. This exact algorithm can be used for simulations of many complex evolutionary problems in biology.

- We elucidated the role of environmental variability on the pace of evolution. Specifically, we have shown that periodic passages of a microbial population through "bottlenecks" at which a significan part of the population is pruned, slows down fixation of beneficial mutations. This result has important applications for synthetic biology that is concerned with evolutionary stability of synthetic  circuits.

- We developed  an experimental microfluidic platform for measuring the fitness levels of specific genotypes in fluctuating environments. We tested this platform by monitoring a mixed culture of two yeast strains that differ in their ability to respond to changes in carbon source yet exhibit the same fitness level in static conditions. Our results further underscored the selective power of environmental fluctuations on seemingly slight phenotypic differences in cellular response dynamics.

- As part of our educational outreach we have developed an elementary school science program. This program integrates UCSD graduate students into the teaching of hands-on science at a partner elementary school.
